newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait mulls attracting more foreign investors.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait mulls attracting more foreign investors.

text.p: Kuwait is considering several steps to attract foreign investment including easing ownership limitations in local firms, a minister said on Tuesday.
"We have issued a decree to form a committee to study all matters in the area of foreign capital," Commerce and Industry Minister Jassem al-Mudaf told Reuters.

"The purpose is to encourage and attract foreign investors," said the minister adding that the committee would study changes to a trade law which limits foreign ownership in local firms to a maximum stake of 49 percent.
Trade in Kuwaiti shares is also restricted to nationals of Gulf Arab states. Any change to the law requires approval by parliament and the Emir Sheikh Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah.

"Who would want to put his money in a third world country company without having a say in what it does with it?" said an economist. "Good economy signs are not the only ingredients to make money, regulations should be on your side."
Visiting officials often tell Kuwaiti counterparts that limitations on ownership discourages foreign investors.
The new committee is made up of investment, finance, industry and stock exchange officials, members of the chamber of commerce and two technical experts, Mudaf said.
"We have pointed out that we want the results soon," he said when asked about a timeframe for the envisaged amendments.

Kuwait also plans to cut taxes imposed on foreign firms operating in Kuwait, officials earlier told Reuters. A foreign company with an annual profit of $1.25 million or more pays a maximum tax of 55 percent according to a three-decade-old law.
Mudaf would not say if the proposed changes would include allowing foreign firms a stake in the crude oil sector -- seen by economists as the most attractive for foreign investors.
"The committee will determine the types of firms" to be affected by the new measures, he added.

The state controls the strategic oil sector which is forecast in the annual budget to June 30 to bring in almost 90 percent of total revenues of three billion dinars ($9.9 billion) although it plans to privatise some local fuel stations and has allowed an American company a stake in a petrochemicals complex.
